<[silence:3400]>
"Telescope pioneer. Physics rebel."
<[silence:2400]>
His full name was Galileo Galilei—Galileo because his family repeated names like a tradition, like calling two sons "John" in a row.
<[silence:2400]>
Most know him as the man who proved Earth wasn’t the center of the universe.<[silence:1200]> Fewer know he did it by turning a spyglass—a toy for Dutch merchants—into a tool that could see Jupiter’s moons.<[silence:2400]>
In 1609, he heard rumors of a "Dutch perspective glass" that made distant ships look close.<[silence:1200]> Without ever seeing one, he built his own in 24 hours.<[silence:1200]> His version? A lead pipe with two lenses—one flat, one curved—like stacking reading glasses wrong to make things sharper, not blurrier.<[silence:2400]>
By January 1610, he spotted three "stars" near Jupiter that refused to stay still.<[silence:1200]> Four nights later, he saw a fourth.<[silence:1200]> They orbited Jupiter like a tiny solar system—a direct challenge to the Church’s teaching that all celestial bodies circled Earth.<[silence:2400]>
He named them the Medicean Stars (now Galileo’s moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, Callisto) to flatter his patron, Cosimo de’ Medici.<[silence:1200]> Smart politics.<[silence:1200]> Terrible science.<[silence:2400]>
His other trick? Rolling balls down grooved ramps to measure speed.<[silence:1200]> No stopwatches existed, so he used his pulse and a water clock.<[silence:1200]> He proved heavy and light objects fall at the same rate—legend says he dropped cannonballs from the Leaning Tower of Pisa, though no records confirm it.<[silence:2400]>
The Church forced him to recant his findings in 1633.<[silence:1200]> Under house arrest, he wrote Two New Sciences—a book on motion and materials—smuggled to Holland in 1638.<[silence:1200]> It became the foundation of modern physics.<[silence:2400]>
His telescope magnified 20x.<[silence:1200]> Today’s amateur scopes do 100x.<[silence:1200]> Yet his real tool was stubbornness: he trusted his eyes over 2,000-year-old philosophy.<[silence:2400]>
Lens grinding.<[silence:1200]>
Inquisition trials.<[silence:1200]>
The birth of experimental science.
